Reported Details: Publishers accuse Cohere of improperly using at least 4,000 copyrighted works to train its large language model and of displaying large portions of or entire articles for users while bypassing visits to the publishers' websites.

In May 2020, Thomson Reuters sued ROSS Intelligence, alleging the company unlawfully copied content from Thomson Reuter’s legal research platform. In February 2025, the court granted summary judgement that the copying was not fair use.
A broad coalition of Canada’s major news organizations sue OpenAI, alleging the AI company is illegally using news articles to train ChatGPT.

Publishers accuse Cohere of improperly using at least 4,000 copyrighted works to train its large language model and of displaying large portions of or entire articles for users while bypassing visits to the publishers' websites.

Publishers accuse Cohere of improperly using at least 4,000 copyrighted works to train its large language model and of displaying large portions of or entire articles for users while bypassing visits to the publishers' websites.

Dow Jones and the New York Post accuse Perplexity of copying copyrighted content. The suit alleges that the AI company can serve up parts or all of publishers’ articles in response to user queries, especially through its premium service, Perplexity Pro.

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: Dow Jones → The Wall Street Journal

Reported Details: The lawsuit alleges OpenAI's theft of the publisher's content infringes on its rights under U.S. copyright and trademark laws

The Brazilian daily newspaper alleges OpenAI uses its content to train AI models without authorization or payment. The outlet demands that OpenAI destroy the AI models that used its protected material.

News Org(s): Danish Press Publications’ Collective Management Organization
Reported Details: The industry group representing almost all of Denmark's media outlets, sues OpenAI for using its repertoire in its training and not respecting "reservations in terms and conditions of a website."
Plaintiff: Danish Press Publications’ Collective Management Organization

News Org(s): Los Angeles Daily News Publishing Company
Reported Details: The lawsuit, filed by nine newspapers owned or managed by MediaNews Group, alleges OpenAI and Microsoft violated copyright law by stealing the publishers' content to build and operate the LLMs that power their AI applications. The plaintiffs seek “in excess of $10 billion” in damages.
Plaintiff: Los Angeles Daily News Publishing Company

Reported Details: The New York Times becomes the first major media company to sue AI companies for copyright infringement, alleging OpenAI and Microsoft's "unlawful use of The Times's work to create artificial intelligence products that compete with it threatens The Times's ability to provide that service." The complaint "seeks to hold them responsible for the billions of dollars in statutory and actual damages that they owe for the unlawful copying and use of The Time's uniquely valuable works."

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: The New York Times Company → The New York Times
The New York Times Company → The Athletic
The New York Times Company → Wirecutter

Reported Details: Publishers accuse Cohere of improperly using at least 4,000 copyrighted works to train its large language model and of displaying large portions of or entire articles for users while bypassing visits to the publishers' websites.
A broad coalition of Canada’s major news organizations sue OpenAI, alleging the AI company is illegally using news articles to train ChatGPT.

Indian news agency Asian News International (ANI) sues OpenAI for unauthorized use of its content. The publisher also claims that ChatGPT falsely attributed fabricated news stories to the agency, damaging its reputation and potentially spreading misinformation. ANI seeks damages and a permanent injunction against OpenAI for using the agency’s content.

Raw Story and Alternet allege OpenAI trained its chatbot using copyrighted works by journalists without properly crediting or citing them. The companies seek damages in the amount of at least $2,500 per violation, and ask OpenAI to remove all copyrighted articles from data training sets. (See latest status updates: https://www.bakerlaw.com/in-re-openai-inc-copyright-infringement-litigation/)

Japan's largest newspaper alleges Perplexity acquired 119,467 Yomiuri articles without permission between February and June 2025 for the purpose of generating answers for its users, which the newspaper claims this violated the right of reproduction and the right to public transmission under the Copyright Law. The suit demands that the company stop using its articles and seeks damages of about ¥2.17 billion, or about $15 million.

Ziff Davis sues OpenAI for “intentionally and relentlessly" reproducing exact copies and creating derivatives of its brands' works, infringing on the publisher’s copyrights and diluting its trademarks.

The lawsuit alleges that OpenAI and Microsoft have been "purloining millions of the Publishers' copyrighted articles without permission and without payment," and that their products removed copyright management information like journalists' names and titles from their work when the information they reported was cited in outputs.
The Intercept seeks damages in the amount of at least $2,500 per copyright infringement violation, as well as asking OpenAI to remove all copyrighted articles from data training sets.

Publishers s accuse the company of improperly using at least 4,000 copyrighted works to train its large language model and of displaying large portions of or entire articles for users while bypassing visits to the publishers' websites
The lawsuit alleges the companies used the nonprofit news organizations' content without permission or offering compensation

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: Center for Investigative Reporting → Mother Jones

Reported Details: Publishers accuse Cohere of improperly using at least 4,000 copyrighted works to train its large language model and of displaying large portions of or entire articles for users while bypassing visits to the publishers' websites.
Penske's antitrust suit alleges that Google illegally uses its journalism to power AI summaries, which reduces traffic to its sites

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: Penske Media Corporation → The Hollywood Reporter
Penske Media Corporation → Fairchild Media Group → Sourcing Journal
Penske Media Corporation → Fairchild Media Group → WWD (Women's Wear Daily)
Penske Media Corporation → Fairchild Media Group

Reported Details: Japanese media giants Nikkei and Asahi Shimbun jointly sue Perplexity over alleged copyright infringement, including ignoring robots.txt and accessing paywalled content. The publishers seek ¥2.2B ($15M) each in damages and deletion of stored content.

The Digital News Publishers Association files an intervention in the Delhi High Court to join an ongoing proceeding against OpenAI, filed first by news agency ANI in 2024, for improperly using copyrighted content.

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: Digital News Publishers Association → The Indian Express
Digital News Publishers Association → Hindustan Times
Digital News Publishers Association → The Hindu
Digital News Publishers Association → India Today Group

Reported Details: WAN-IFRA announces the expansion of its Newsroom AI Catalyst program that will feature two additional cohorts, open to 24 editorial teams, and will expand to new regions, including Australia and New Zealand.

The Online News Association, with financial support from Microsoft, launches the AI in Journalism Initiative, with the goal of "connect[ing] digital innovators and newsroom leaders with year-round programming to build practical skills, knowledge and the capacity to swiftly harness opportunities presented by the latest shifts in AI"

OpenAI and Microsoft announce a $10 million AI collaborative and fellowship program operated by the Lenfest Institute, which will provide $500,000 each to five U.S. metro news organizations to cover the cost of hiring a two-year AI fellow to work on projects that focus on driving sustainable businesses for local news.

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: Lenfest Institute → The Minnesota Star Tribune

Reported Details: Semafor launches a new, global multi-source breaking news feed called Signals, in which journalists use tools from Microsoft and OpenAI to offer readers "diverse, sophisticated perspectives and insights on the biggest stories in the world as they develop." The Financial Times reports that "the companies would not share financial details, but the amount of money is 'substantial' to Semafor’s business."

News Org(s): New York University’s Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute
Reported Details: New York University’s Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute launches the Ethics and Journalism Initiative, backed by a $395,000 grant from OpenAI

JournalismAI, a project of Polis – the journalism think-tank at the London School of Economics and Political Science – announces a new grant program with the Google News Initiative "to enable 35 news organisations around the world to experiment, implement and share best practice across AI technologies." The grants - which range between $50,000 and $250,000 - will be targeted in three areas: experimentation of new formats across mobile, video and audio; identification of ways to grow subscriptions and support diverse forms of revenue; and fighting misinformation.

Microsoft partners with Nota, "a startup dedicated to putting high-quality AI tools into newsrooms to help improve newsroom operations, has expanded to more than a 100 newsrooms with support from Microsoft"

Launched in partnership with OpenAI, WAN-IFRA's Newsroom AI Catalyst is "an accelerator program designed to help newsrooms fast-track their AI adoption and implementation to bring efficiencies and create quality content." The program is said to support over 100 news publishers.

FT Strategies, the growth consultancy from the Financial Times, partners with the Google News Initiatives to launch The AI Launchpad, "a five-month hands-on programme that engages a group of 8 publishers on a journey to craft an ambitious and responsible vision for AI in their organisation, guiding them through live experiments to test their ideas"

Microsoft partners with The GroundTruth Project, which sends local journalists into newsrooms around the world through its Report for America and Report for the World programs. The project will add an AI track of work for its corps members through the AI in Local News initiative with the goal of helping make reporting and newsrooms themselves more efficient and sustainable for the future

OpenAI is commits $5 million to the American Journalism Project to support the expansion of AJP’s work and up to $5 million in OpenAI API credits to help its grantee organizations "assess and deploy emerging AI technologies within their organizations"

Google agrees to pay News Corp between $5 million and $6 million annually to fund its development of new artificial intelligence-related content and products. The arrangement follows Google's recent termination of another content partnership with The Wall Street Journal, which resulted in layoffs at the publication

News Org(s): Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism
Reported Details: Perplexity donates $250,000 to Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism towards research into the future of AI and news. The school's Knight Lab will also receive access to Perplexity’s data, staff and publisher partners so it can learn how news content shows up in the chatbot’s responses and how newsrooms are approaching AI.

ProPublica joins the Lenfest Institute AI Collaborative and Fellowship Program to "launch AI experiments in partnership with OpenAI and Microsoft." The publisher will "explore using an AI-powered system to help its engagement team categorize and route investigative news tip submissions — aiming to ensure that journalists quickly receive relevant leads while safeguarding source anonymity. The AI Fellow will also work with ProPublica’s journalists on other possible investigative news projects."

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: Lenfest Institute → The Dallas Morning News
Lenfest Institute → Arizona State University’s NEWSWELL

Reported Details: American Journalism Project awards "one- to two-year grants, ranging from $25,000 to $200,000," funded by OpenAI, to a cohort of 13 of its portfolio organizations

American Journalism Project → The Nebraska Journalism Trust

News Org(s): Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism
Reported Details: Microsoft partners with The Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY to invite experienced journalists to a tuition-free program to explore ways to incorporate generative AI into their work and newsrooms in a three-month hybrid and highly interactive program

Microsoft partners with publishers for its Copilot Daily feature, which generates audio summaries of current events and weather pulled from "authorized content sources." The company says it plans to add more sources over time. Financial terms are not disclosed.

In addition to bringing Italian-language content to users of ChatGPT and the SearchGPT prototype, the strategic partnership "also opens opportunities for both organizations to further collaborate on AI features and applications that can enhance the way readers access and interact with news in Italy." Financial terms are not disclosed.

The partnership enables OpenAI to incorporate content from more than 20 magazine brands and 40+ newspapers into its AI products. Hearst’s other businesses outside of magazines and newspapers are not included in the partnership. Financial terms are not disclosed.

parent_child_matches.lineage_str: Hearst → Hearst Newspapers → San Francisco Chronicle

Reported Details: The multi-year agreement allows Amazon to use the Times' editorial content in "a variety of ... customer experiences," including "real-time display of summaries and short excerpts of Times content within Amazon products and services, such as Alexa, and training Amazon’s proprietary foundation models." The Wall Street Journal reports that the tech giant will pay the Times at between $20 and $25 million annually to license its content.

Reported Details: The multi-year agreement allows Amazon to license content for use in its AI shopping assistant Rufus. Financial terms are not disclosed.

The multi-year partnership allows Mistral's conversational AI assistant, Le Chat, to access the full range of AFP's text stories. Financial terms are not disclosed.

The multi-year agreement does not involve the use of Le Monde content to train Perplexity's LLM; it only concerns the use of our content to generate answers to questions. The agreement also grants the publisher access to Sonar, an answer engine that will be rolled out on its site and apps. Financial terms are not disclosed.

The multi-year deal - the first of its kind - allows Meta to user Reuters' news content to provide real-time answers to user queries about news and current events in its Meta AI chatbot. It is unclear whether the partnership includes a licensing component that would allow Meta to use Reuters' journalism to train Meta's large language model, Llama. Financial terms are not disclosed.
Gannett Chairman and CEO announced that the publisher was partnering with Microsoft on the upcoming launch of the Publisher Content Marketplace. Financial terms were not disclosed.
The partnership allows OpenAI to integrate content from a selection of Schibsted Media Group's titles, into OpenAI's products, including ChatGPT. Financial terms are not disclosed.
The multi-year partnership with enables OpenAI to display the publisher's content within its products, including the SearchGPT prototype. Financial terms are not disclosed.

The multi-faceted partnership allows OpenAI to license Vox's archive content to train its AI models, and gives Vox the opportunity to leverage the AI technology to power new journalism projects. Financial terms are not disclosed.

The partnership will deliver ChatGPT users "summaries of selected global news content from Axel Springer’s media brands... including otherwise paid content." According to the Wall Street Journal, "is worth at least $25 million to $30 million over three years."

The multi-year content deal and strategic partnership gives OpenAI access to TIME's archives from the last 101 years to train its large language models and use for responses to user queries in its consumer-facing products, as well as access to real-time content to help answer user queries as news unfolds. The deal also gives TIME access to OpenAI's tech and tools to develop new products for its audience. Financial terms are not disclosed.

The strategic partnership will allow ChatGPT users to access content from across Future's portfolio, "with attribution and links to the full original articles for transparency and further information." Financial terms are not disclosed.

The multi-year partnership permits OpenAI to display content from New Corp's major news and information publications in response to user questions and to "enhance its products." The Wall Street Journal reports the deal could be worth more than $250 million over five years, including compensation in the form of cash and credits for the use of OpenAI technology.

The arrangement will also give the publisher's product team privileged access to OpenAI tech and the opportunity to give feedback and share use-cases "to shape and improve future news experiences in ChatGPT and other OpenAI products." According to the agreement, OpenAI will license "part of AP’s text archive, while AP will leverage OpenAI’s technology and product expertise." Financial terms of the deal are not disclosed, but the Wall Street Journal reports that the deal is "in the single-digit millions a year."

As part of the strategic partnership and licensing agreement, "OpenAI will display content and links attributed to Dotdash Meredith (DDM) in relevant ChatGPT responses. OpenAI will also collaborate with DDM to create new AI products and features for its readers and use historical and ongoing DDM content to enhance its model's performance." According to public financial documents from DDM's parent company, IAC, OpenAI is paying the publisher a minimum of around $16 million per year to license its content.

The "expanded, multifaceted partnership across advertising, AI, content and cloud computing" includes extending an adtech collaboration to the US, powering new AI experiences and monetization, enhanced content offerings through Microsoft Start-MSN, and Microsoft Azure expansion. Financial terms are not disclosed.
Associated Press announced that it will be launch partner for Microsoft's Publisher Content Marketplace. Financial terms were not disclosed.

The strategic content licensing agreement enables Perplexity to integrate content from USA TODAY and the USA TODAY Network's 200+ local publications into its AI-powered search experiences. Additionally, Gannett will have access to Perplexity's Sonar API and Enterprise Pro for all employees. Financial terms are not disclosed.

Reported Details: The News/Media Alliance's licensing partnership with ProRata allows members to opt into a content license with the startup for use with its Gist.AI product. "ProRata’s attribution technology will identify when publisher content is used in generative AI answers, attribute the information to them, and pay them 50% of revenues for the use of their content."
Content from USA TODAY and 27 USA TODAY Network publications will be available for Perplexity's new agentic browser Comet.

Reported Details: The strategic partnership enables to ChatGPT's search tool to "display summaries, quotes, and links to original reporting from The Post in response to relevant questions." Financial terms are not disclosed.

As part of the content partnership,"ChatGPT will use Axios journalism to answer user queries with attributed summaries, quotes and links to Axios stories. Axios can access OpenAI's technology to build its own AI products, processes, and systems." The deal also includes funding to help Axios build new newsrooms in four new U.S. cities: Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Kansas City, Missouri; Boulder, Colorado; and Huntsville, Alabama. Financial terms are not disclosed.

People Inc. CEO Neil Vogel announced to shareholders that the publisher had struck an AI licensing deal with Microsoft to be part of the tech company's pay-per-usage AI content marketplace. Financial terms were not disclosed.
